The first statement is a conditional statement: "If Joe went to the park, then Lucy went to the zoo." This means that if the antecedent (Joe went to the park) is true, then the consequent (Lucy went to the zoo) must also be true.

The second statement is a simple statement: "Lucy went to the zoo." This means that the consequent of the first statement is true.

Now, the question is whether we can conclude that the antecedent of the first statement is also true, i.e., "Joe went to the park."

The logical rule that applies here is called "Modus Ponens." This rule states that if we have a conditional statement (if P, then Q) and the antecedent (P) is true, then we can conclude that the consequent (Q) is also true.

However, in this case, we do not have the antecedent (Joe went to the park) as a given statement. We only have the consequent (Lucy went to the zoo) as a given statement.

Therefore, we cannot conclude that the antecedent (Joe went to the park) is true based on the information provided.
